title: Jan Mikulicz-Radecki
text:
Jan Mikulicz-Radecki () was a German Polish-Austrian <a href="surgery">surgeon</a> who worked mainly in the German Empire. He was born on 16 May 1850 in <a href="Czerniowce">Czerniowce</a> in the <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Austrian Empire</a> (present-day <a href="Chernivtsi">Chernivtsi</a> in <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>) and died on 4 June 1905 in <a href="Breslau">Breslau</a>, <a href="German%20Empire">German Empire</a>. He was professor in <a href="Krak%C3%B3w">Kraków</a>, <a href="Wroc%C5%82aw">Wrocław</a>, and <a href="K%C3%B6nigsberg">Królewiec</a> (Königsberg). He was the inventor of new operating techniques and tools, and is one of the pioneers of <a href="antiseptics">antiseptics</a> and aseptic techniques. In <a href="Poland">Poland</a> he is regarded as one of the founders of the Kraków school of surgery.
His parental ancestors of the Mikulicz family were of <a href="Poles">Polish</a> "<a href="szlachta">szlachta</a>" origin and had been granted the <a href="Gozdawa%20coat%20of%20arms">Gozdawa coat of arms</a> by King <a href="John%20III%20Sobieski">John III Sobieski</a> after the 1683 <a href="Battle%20of%20Vienna">Battle of Vienna</a>. His mother Freiin von Damnitz was of Austrian descent. Mikulicz-Radecki spoke his native Polish, and also German, Russian and English fluently. When asked his nationality he simply answered "surgeon". After finishing studies at the <a href="University%20of%20Vienna">University of Vienna</a> under <a href="Theodor%20Billroth">Theodor Billroth</a>, he was a director of surgery at the <a href="Jagiellonian%20University">Jagiellonian University</a> in <a href="Krak%C3%B3w">Kraków</a>, the <a href="University%20of%20K%C3%B6nigsberg">University of Königsberg</a> (Królewiec, <a href="Kaliningrad">Kaliningrad</a>) and from 1890 at the <a href="University%20of%20Wroc%C5%82aw">University of Wrocław</a>.
Mikulicz-Radecki's innovations in operative technique for a wide variety of diseases helped develop modern surgery. He contributed prodigiously to <a href="cancer">cancer</a> surgery, especially on organs of the <a href="digestive%20system">digestive system</a>. He was first to suture a perforated <a href="gastric%20ulcer">gastric ulcer</a> (1885), surgically restore part of the <a href="oesophagus">oesophagus</a> (1886), remove a malignant part of the <a href="Colon%20%28anatomy%29">colon</a> (1903), and describe what is now known as <a href="Benign%20lymphoepithelial%20lesion">Mikulicz’ disease</a>.
In 1881, he developed improved models of the <a href="Esophagogastroduodenoscopy">esophagoscope</a> and <a href="gastroscope">gastroscope</a>. As an ardent advocate of <a href="antiseptic">antiseptic</a>s, he did much to popularize <a href="Joseph%20Lister%2C%201st%20Baron%20Lister">Joseph Lister</a>'s antiseptic methods. He created a <a href="surgical%20mask">surgical mask</a> and was the first to use <a href="medical%20gloves">medical gloves</a> during surgery.
Mikulicz-Radecki was a talented amateur pianist and a friend of <a href="Johannes%20Brahms">Johannes Brahms</a>.
He received an honorary doctorate (<a href="Legum%20Doctor">LL.D</a>) from the <a href="University%20of%20Glasgow">University of Glasgow</a> in June 1901.
